title: Paris's late-night restaurants are disappearing. Step inside the few remaining ones
summary: A few gastronomic institutions still welcome Parisian night owls for a late-night boiled egg with morels or a grilled pig's trotter. But they are becoming increasingly rare.

title: Syrian rebels enter Aleppo in ongoing major offensive
summary: Turkey-backed jihadists launched a surprise offensive this week in Syria, killing 255 and displacing 14,000 people.

title: Macron vows to aid Ukraine 'as intensely and as long as necessary' against Russian escalation
summary: Russia has used a new hypersonic missile against Ukraine in response to Ukraine's use of US and British missiles inside Russian-held territory. Amid Russia's threats of a repeat response, it has upped its attacks with drones and other missiles. France has said that Ukraine's use of French missiles remains 'an option.'

title: S&P maintains France economy rating and outlook
summary: Despite debt and political troubles, the country received a 'stable' outlook rating on Friday from the ratings agency. Prime Minister Michel Barnier had just announced a major concession on Thursday to end a standoff with the opposition over budget.

title: Against oblivion: French researchers draw up an inventory of Gaza's heritage
summary: Led by historian Fabrice Virgili, a team of some 30 academics is documenting the state of UNESCO-listed heritage in the Gaza Strip, where two-thirds of the buildings have already been destroyed by the Israeli army.

title: The thrills and chills of French cinema
summary: Like Emma Benestan's 'Animale,' French productions are no longer afraid to tackle horror, the paranormal or the fantastic.

title: More than 3,000 fake Gibson guitars seized at Los Angeles port
summary: Had the guitars been authentic, they would have been worth $18 million, US Customs and Border Protection said in a statement. The agency said Gibson confirmed the guitars that were intercepted were counterfeit. 'This is really emotional and personal for us,' said Beth Heidt, chief marketing officer at Gibson.

title: Post-ceasefire, strengthening Lebanon's army remains a challenge
summary: The ceasefire agreement signed with Israel calls for the Lebanese Armed Forces to deploy 10,000 soldiers in southern Lebanon. A plan to reinforce the LAF in the region is under discussion with Beirut's Western allies.

title: UK lawmakers advance assisted dying bill
summary: UK MPs voted 330 to 275 in favor of legalizing assisted dying for terminally ill adults, marking the first Commons vote on the issue in nearly a decade. The contentious bill now moves to the committee stage.

title: Tales from the Feminist Collective Against Rape helpline: 'You did the right thing by calling us'
summary: For nearly 40 years, the Rapes Women Information helpline has provided victims a space to share their experiences and receive support, in the aim of 'clearing away the fog that the agressor has put in [their] mind.'

title: At the Pogba trial, the resentments of a group of friends perverted by money
summary: The six defendants in the attempted extortion case against the international football player have been appearing in court in Paris since Tuesday.

title: France demands UK share responsibility for Channel border security
summary: France's interior minister, Bruno Retailleau, criticized Britain for outsourcing Channel border security to France, urging an EU-UK deal. Seventy-two people have died trying to reach Britain from northern France this year.

title: Ukrainian energy infrastructure heavily hit by Russian drones and missiles
summary: During a visit to Kazakhstan, Russian President Vladimir Putin said that Thursday's air raids targeting Kyiv were 'a response' to Kyiv's use of American and British missiles against Russian territory.

title: How the petrochemical lobby is stalling global treaty negotiations on plastic pollution
summary: At least 220 representatives from the fossil fuel and chemical industries are taking part in negotiations for a global treaty in Busan. They are opposing any reduction in plastic production.

title: Merkel's memoirs get mixed reactions in Germany
summary: The publication of the former German Chancellor's memoirs has sparked nostalgia, but also criticism, over the lack of regret expressed by the Christian Democratic figure, who led Germany from 2005 to 2021.

title: Bernard Arnault gives witness testimony at ex-spy chief trial: 'I'm not answering these stupid questions!'
summary: Faced with numerous questions from the defense team, the LVMH CEO quickly lost his cool.

title: Bassirou Diomaye Faye: 'There will soon be no more French troops in Senegal'
summary: In an interview with Le Monde, the Senegalese president, an advocate of sovereigntist policy, discusses the 1944 Thiaroye massacre and the relationship he intends to forge with France, whose influence is increasingly being challenged in French-speaking Africa.

title: Chad breaks off defense agreement with France, a slap in the face for Paris
summary: There is no indication that Paris had been informed prior to the announcement, made as French Foreign Minister Jean-Noël Barrot was visiting N'Djamena on Thursday.

title: Georgia halts EU application, leading to protests denouncing a betrayal
summary: On Thursday, the government announced the postponement of negotiations on its membership application until the end of 2028. Demonstrations broke out, supported by pro-European President Salome Zurabishvili, who is calling for resistance.

title: From Dubai to Belem, three crucial years for climate action
summary: After the half-hearted conclusion of COP29 in Baku, less than four years remain to try to curb the volume of greenhouse gas emissions in order to limit global warming to +1.5°C by the end of the century.

title: Russian ruble plunges to a two-year low
summary: President Vladimir Putin assured the public that there was no need to 'panic,' and the central bank took action. Despite the Kremlin's assurances, concerns are growing among both the general public and industrial leaders.

title: The efforts of Venice-area residents to 'take back' their city marred by drug trafficking and corruption
summary: Mestre is a borough just a few kilometers from the Italian floating city but is beset by poverty and insecurity. Condemning the lack of action by local authorities, residents are setting up initiatives to recreate a sense of community.

title: Zelensky says NATO guarantees can end 'hot stage' of war
summary: This week, Russia has threatened to strike government buildings in Kyiv and launched a massive aerial attack on Ukraine's energy sector, which it called a response to Ukraine firing US and British-supplied missiles on Russian territory.

title: At far-right leader Jordan Bardella's book signings: 'Look, he's like an influencer'
summary: Across southern France, the Rassemblement National party leader has been a big hit, especially with young people. His supporters are certain that he can respond to their concerns about immigration, security and purchasing power, and believe he is helping to modernize the far-right party.

title: In Kenya, a single mother 'crisis'
summary: As part of a series exploring parenting abroad, this week, 'Le Monde' looks at working-class districts of Nairobi, where many women are forced to bring up their children alone without any help – a growing phenomenon.

title: Explosion at Kosovo canal feeding key power plants labeled a 'terrorist attack' by PM
summary: The blast occurred near the town of Zubin Potok in the country's troubled north, damaging a canal supplying water to cooling systems at two power plants that generate most of Kosovo's electricity.

title: Canadian PM Trudeau in Florida to meet Trump as tariff threats loom
summary: A smiling Trudeau was seen exiting a hotel in West Palm Beach before arriving at Mar-a-Lago, making him the latest high-profile guest of Trump, whose impending second term  is already overshadowing the last few months of Biden's administration.

title: Vote counting begins in tight three-way Irish election race
summary: The three main parties were deadlocked in an exit poll after voting finished on Friday. Counting starts on Saturday morning, but could take several days due to Ireland's system of proportional representation.

title: Macron's 'successful gamble' with Notre-Dame
summary: On Friday, the French president attempted to turn the cathedral's timely restoration into a 'metaphor for the life of the nation.'

title: From Paris to Los Angeles, the dream life of pianist prodigy Sofiane Pamart
summary: The French artist from Lille who's now based in Los Angeles, played at the opening ceremonies of the Paris Olympics and the Césars movie awards.

title: Georgia police say 107 arrested at pro-EU protest
summary: The prime minister Irakli's statement that Georgia will not seek to open accession talks with the European Union until 2028 ignited a furious reaction from the opposition and two days of protests.

title: International law and French opportunism
summary: The French Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu would be granted immunity if he visits France. This announcement could be interpreted by Israel as a kind of carte blanche to continue the war in Gaza.

title: French army's forced retreat from Africa continues
summary: Chad's announcement that it is breaking off its defense agreement with Paris, followed by Senegal's declaration that it plans to send French soldiers home, indicate France's failure to redefine the former colonial power's military posture on the continent.

title: Syria at the center of Israel's strategy to prevent Hezbollah from rebuilding its arsenal
summary: For the past two months, Israel has been bombing its neighbor in order to prevent the Shiite party from transporting weapons and reinforcements to its Lebanese strongholds.

title: 'Hiding Saddam Hussein,' by Halkawt Mustafa: Testimony from  the farmer who hid the Iraqi dictator
summary: This documentary recounts the extraordinary story of Alaa Namiq, a kindly farmer who met and sheltered the former president of the Iraqi Republic for eight months in 2003.

title: Brazil's restoration of the 'Atlantic Forest' is beginning to bear fruit
summary: The rainforest that once covered around 15% of Brazil has shrunk by more than three-quarters. However, initiatives are multiplying, notably to reforest Rio de Janeiro.

title: Syrian rebels take control of most of Aleppo, as Russian air strikes reported
summary: Russian air strikes were reported in Syria's second city for the first time since 2016 as rebel fighters took control of the city's airport as part of their lightning attack.

title: French budget: S&P encourages  Barnier to stick with his austerity plan
summary: On Friday, the world's leading credit rating agency kept France's credit rating unchanged, but expressed concern about the 'considerable risk' that the government's planned cost-cutting measures will not materialize.

title: World Central Kitchen 'pauses operations in Gaza' after Israeli strike
summary: The Israeli military confirmed that a Palestinian employee of  World Central Kitchen was killed Saturday after Gaza rescuers announced the deaths of three aid workers following an Israeli air strike.

title: In Germany, economic decline is looming
summary: Germany, the driving force behind Europe, is currently experiencing severe economic and political turbulence, enough to rekindle deep-seated identity anxieties.

title: Spanish floods reveal an overlooked issue: The impact of climate disasters on working life
summary: While heatwaves are beginning to be considered, other impacts, such as flooding, are not looked at from a business perspective. Teleworking is a useful tool in response to these uncertainties.

title: Young adults' contradictory relationship with money
summary: The financial behaviors of young people stand out in numerous ways and confuse many with their paradoxes, shaped by the challenges of the times.
